accordionItems.title: How it works
accordionItems.content: The 4-7-8 technique activates the parasympathetic nervous system through controlled breathing. The increased breath hold raises carbon dioxide levels in the blood, signaling the brain to relax.

accordionItems.title: Why it's effective
accordionItems.content: The 4-7-8 ratio creates optimal balance between activation and relaxation. The 4-count inhale prepares the body, the 7-count hold allows oxygen absorption, and the 8-count exhale fully clears the lungs and calms the nervous system.

accordionItems.title: When to use
accordionItems.content: Perfect for emergency situations: panic attacks, pre-event stress, insomnia, anxiety. Can be practiced any time of day, especially before sleep or during moments of strong excitement.

accordionItems.title: Practical tips
accordionItems.content: Start with 3-4 cycles, gradually increasing to 8. Breathe quietly to avoid attracting attention. If you feel dizzy - take a break. Works best in a quiet place, but can be practiced in public spaces too.

breathing-square.title: Square Breathing
breathing-square.subtitle: Stabilization in stressful situations
tips: Follow the dot moving around the square

accordionItems.title: Technique mechanics
accordionItems.content: Square breathing is based on an even rhythm of 4-4-4-4. Each breathing phase lasts the same time, creating a symmetrical pattern. Visualizing movement around a square helps focus and maintain rhythm.

accordionItems.title: Why it works
accordionItems.content: The even rhythm activates the vagus nerve, which is responsible for the rest state. Breathing symmetry calms the nervous system and reduces cortisol levels. Visual concentration distracts from anxious thoughts.

accordionItems.title: Application
accordionItems.content: Effective for acute stress, anxiety, panic attacks. Helps before important meetings, exams, public speaking. Can be used anytime when you need quick emotional state stabilization.

accordionItems.title: Recommendations
accordionItems.content: Start with 2-3 cycles, gradually increasing to 10. Monitor comfort - if you feel tension, slow down the pace. Best practiced sitting with straight back, but can be done standing or lying down.

grounding-5-4-3-2-1.title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
grounding-5-4-3-2-1.subtitle: Using senses for stabilization
tips: Take your time, pause between steps

accordionItems.title: How it works
accordionItems.content: The 5-4-3-2-1 technique activates all five senses, helping the brain switch from anxious thoughts to reality. This creates a sense of stability and presence in the moment.

accordionItems.title: Why it's effective
accordionItems.content: Activating the senses stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system, reducing stress levels. Focusing on specific details distracts from anxious thoughts and returns you to the present moment.

accordionItems.title: When to use
accordionItems.content: Perfect for panic attacks, anxiety, dissociation, stress. Can be used anytime and anywhere - at home, work, on public transport.

accordionItems.title: Practical tips
accordionItems.content: Start with what's easiest to notice. Don't criticize yourself for simple answers. If you can't find something for one of the senses, skip it and move to the next.

steps.instruction: Sit comfortably, place feet on the floor
Feel how your feet touch the ground
Imagine roots growing from your feet into the earth

accordionItems.title: How it works
accordionItems.content: Anchor grounding uses visualization and body sensations to create a sense of stability. Imagining roots helps feel connected to the earth and find inner support.

accordionItems.title: Psychological effect
accordionItems.content: The technique activates feelings of safety and stability, reducing cortisol levels. Root visualization creates a metaphorical connection with stability and support.

accordionItems.title: Application
accordionItems.content: Effective for anxiety, stress, feelings of instability. Helps before important events, in moments of uncertainty. Can be practiced sitting or standing.

accordionItems.title: Recommendations
accordionItems.content: Find a quiet place for first practices. Gradually learn to use the technique in any conditions. If visualization doesn't work, just focus on the feeling of your feet on the floor.
